bibl.title: Taxpayers and Their Money in Sixth-Century Egypt: Currency in the Temseu Skordon Codex.
bibl.note: The coin module in terms of which computation was carried out by the accountant in P. Lond. Herm. was the 33-nummi (ΛΓ) copper coin struck at Alexandria by Justinian after 538 CE, which lends itself to ready reckoning as it was equivalent to the round figure of 100 talents of copper. - Avec résumé en anglais.
bibl.seg: Leslie S.B. MacCoull, Taxpayers and Their Money in Sixth-Century Egypt: Currency in the Temseu Skordon Codex.
Journal of Late Antiquity 8 (2015) pp. 97-113, 1 tabl., 1 fig. coul.

The coin module in terms of which computation was carried out by the accountant in P. Lond. Herm. was the 33-nummi (ΛΓ) copper coin struck at Alexandria by Justinian after 538 CE, which lends itself to ready reckoning as it was equivalent to the round figure of 100 talents of copper. - Avec résumé en anglais.
